message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in Fibrillin, a major component of elastic fibers. Laminin is a glycoprotein found in the basement membrane, Type I collagen is found in bone, skin and tendons and Keratin is a structural protein found in hair and nails, none of which are associated with Marfan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a structural protein in connective tissue. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in the structural protein Fibrillin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The joint hypermobility, high-arched palate, and abnormally long/finger toes suggest Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a structural protein involved in the formation of elastic fibers. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation, which is common in Marfan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a structural protein. None of the other options are associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in the gene that encodes for fibrillin, a structural protein that provides strength and elasticity to connective tissues. None of the other options are associated with Marfan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of symptoms, including joint hypermobility, high-arched palate, and lens subluxation, suggests Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a structural protein found in connective tissue. None of the other options play a role in connective tissue functions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s physical examination findings and lens subluxation suggest Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in the fibrillin gene. Laminin and type I collagen are involved in connective tissue but do not cause Marfan syndrome. Keratin is a structural protein found in hair, skin, and nails, and is not involved in connective tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings suggest Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a structural protein that provides strength and elasticity to connective tissues. The other options are not associated with Marfan syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Marfan syndrome, which is caused by a defect in the structural protein Fibrillin. Laminin, Type I collagen, and Keratin are not associated with Marfan syndrome.
